sen.j: 糟屋 武則（かすや たけのり）は安土桃山時代・江戸時代の大名。
sen.e: Takenori KASUYA was a daimyo (feudal warlord) who lived between the Azuchi Momoyama and Edo periods.
Takenori KASUYA was a daimyo (feudal warlord) who lived between the Azuchi Momoyama and Edo periods.

sen.j: 糟屋氏は播磨加古川城を拠点に鎌倉時代から続く武家で、播磨国にて別所氏の家臣であった糟屋忠安の次男。
sen.e: The Kasuya clan existed from the Kamakura period and was a military family based at Kakogawa castle. He was the second son of Tadayasu KASUYA a retainer of the Bessho clan in Harima Province.
The Kasuya clan existed from the Kamakura period and was a military family based at Kakogawa Castle; he was the second son of Tadayasu KASUYA, a retainer of the Bessho clan in Harima Province.

The Kasuya clan existed from the Kamakura period and was a military family based at Kakogawajo Castle in Harima Province; Takenori KASUYA was the second son of Tadayasu KASUYA, a retainer of the Bessho clan in Harima Province.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 兄に糟屋朝正（友政）。
sen.e: Elder brother was Tomomasa.
His elder brother was Tomomasa.

sen.j: 姓は糟屋の他に糟谷・粕屋・加須屋とも記され、有名な名乗りとしては「加須屋真雄（かすやさねかつ）」とも。
sen.e: The family name "Kasuya" (糟屋) is recorded as having been written using different character combinations (糟谷・粕屋・加須屋) and the famous Sanekatsu KASUYA uses the "加須屋" version.
The family name "Kasuya" (糟屋) is recorded as having been written using different character combinations (糟谷・粕屋・加須屋), but the famous Sanekatsu KASUYA uses the "加須屋" version.
The family name "Kasuya" (糟屋) is recorded as having been written using different character combinations (糟谷, 粕屋, 加須屋), but the famous combination used by Sanekatsu KASUYA was"加須屋".

sen.j: 名乗りは他にもあり、数正、宗重、真安、宗孝など、いずれも武則の別名として伝わっており年代によって違うことから、本人の名なのか、子なのか混乱もある。
sen.e: There are also other ways of writing the Sanekatsu (真雄) name in characters (数正,宗重,真安,宗孝 etc) and it is said each was used by Takenori as a different alias depending on the period so, there is confusion whether or not it is referring to Takenori or one of his children at times.

There are also other ways of writing the Sanekatsu (真雄) name in characters (数正,宗重,真安,宗孝 etc.), and it is said that each was used by Takenori as a different alias depending on the period; thus there is confusion as to whether certain usages refer to Takenori or one of his children.

Takenori also had other names (corresponding to Christian name for westerners) as 数正, 宗重, 真安, 宗孝 and so force, each of which was said to have been used by Takenori as an alias depending on the period; thus there is confusion as to whether certain usages refer to Takenori or one of his children.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 甥に弓の名手として名高い加須屋武成がいる。
sen.e: He has a celebrated nephew Takenari KASUYA who was an archery expert.
He had a celebrated nephew, Takenari KASUYA, who was an archery expert.
He had a celebrated nephew, Takenari KASUYA, who was an archery expert.

sen.j: 本姓は志村だったとされている（武則の母が兄朝正を産んだ後、豪族志村氏と再婚し、その際に産まれたのが武則である為。）。
sen.e: His real name was Shimura (because Takenori's mother remarried into the powerful Shimura clan after his elder brother Tomomasa was born and subsequently Takenori's birth).
His real name was Shimura (because Takenori's mother remarried into the powerful Shimura clan after his elder brother Tomomasa was born, and subsequently Takenori was born).
His real name was said to have been Shimura, because Takenori's mother remarried into the powerful Shimura clan after his elder brother Tomomasa was born, and subsequently Takenori was born.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、天正5年（1577年）の豊臣秀吉の播磨攻めの時に朝正が別所長治について三木城に入った為、武則は兄と袂を分かって織田方につき、糟屋の姓を名乗った。
sen.e: However, during the Harima campaign by Toyotomi Hideyoshi in 1577, because Tomomasa had entered Miki castle with Nagaharu BESSHO, Takenori was separated from his brother and for the Oda camp used the name "Kasuya" with him.

However, during the Harima campaign by Toyotomi Hideyoshi in 1577, because Tomomasa had entered Miki Castle with Nagaharu BESSHO, Takenori became separated from his brother and for the Oda camp used the name "Kasuya" with them.

However, during the Harima campaign by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in 1577, because Tomomasa had entered Mikijo Castle with Nagaharu BESSHO, Takenori became separated from his brother and went for the Oda camp used the name Kasuya with them.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: その後武則は黒田孝高の推挙により羽柴秀吉の小姓頭となっている。
sen.e: Subsequently Takenori became a page to Hideyoshi HASHIBA upon the recommendation of Yoshitaka KURODA.
Subsequently, Takenori became a page to Hideyoshi HASHIBA upon the recommendation of Yoshitaka KURODA.

sen.j: そして天正11年（1583年）、賤ヶ岳の戦いで武則は佐久間盛政配下の宿屋七左衛門という武士を討ち取るなどして活躍し、福島正則や加藤清正らと共に賤ヶ岳の七本槍の一人に数えられ、その戦功により播磨国に二千石、河内国に一千石など合わせて三千石余を拝領する。
sen.e: During the 1583 battle of Shizugatake, Takenori took an active role in the arrest of a subordinate of Morimasa SAKUMA; the samurai Shichizaemon YADOYA. Takenori is also counted amongst Masanori FUKUSHIMA, Kiyomasa KATO and others as one of the "Seven lancers of Shizugatake".Due to his valor in battle he was awarded 2,000 koku of land in Harima Province and 1,000 koku in Kawachi Province: combined grants in excess of 3,000 koku of land.

During the 1583 battle of Shizugatake, Takenori took an active role in the arrest of a subordinate of Morimasa SAKUMA, the samurai Shichizaemon YADOYA; and Takenori is counted among Masanori FUKUSHIMA, Kiyomasa KATO and others as one of the "seven lancers of Shizugatake";due to his valor in battle, he was awarded 2,000 koku of land in Harima Province and 1,000 koku in Kawachi Province, representing a combined grant exceeding 3,000 koku of land.

sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: その後も小牧・長久手の戦いや九州征伐、小田原征伐などに兵150名を動員して参加している。
sen.e: Subsequently he participated in the battles of Komaki and Nagakute, as well as the conquests of Kyushu and Odawara etc where he mobilized 150 troops.
Subsequently he participated in the battles of Komaki and Nagakute as well as the conquests of Kyushu and Odawara, etc., in which he mobilized 150 troops.

sen.j: また軍事だけでなく、天正14年（1586年）に方広寺大仏の作事奉行を、天正19年（1591年）には近江国検地奉行となって増田長盛らと共に検地を行うなど行政面でも事績を残している。
sen.e: He was not only involved in military matters. In 1586 he administered the building of a grand statue of Buddha at Hokoji Temple and, in 1591 became administrator of land surveys of Omi Province. Together with Nagamori MASHITA undertook land surveys and left behind a legacy in the form of administration of public works.

He was involved in more than military matters, as when, in 1586, he administered the building of a grand statue of Buddha at Hokoji Temple and, in 1591 became the administrator of land surveys of Omi Province; together with Nagamori MASHITA, he undertook land surveys and left behind a legacy in the form of the administration of public works.

sen.j: 更に天正14年（1586年）には従五位下内膳正に任官。
sen.e: In addition, in 1586 was given the court rank of Upper Junior Fifth Rank Principal cupbearer to the Emperor.

sen.j: 後陽成天皇の聚楽第行幸の際にも天皇の行列に供奉している。
sen.e: Attended Emperor Go Yozei while processing during his visit to Hideyoshi Toyotomi`s Jurakudai mansion.
He attended Emperor Go Yozei while processing during his visit to Hideyoshi Toyotomi's Jurakudai mansion.

sen.j: この他文禄の役では目付として朝鮮に渡海しており、文禄元年（1592年）には新庄直忠らとともに朝鮮人逃亡流民の帰郷を促す訓令を発布するほか、同年に第一次、翌文禄2年（1593年）には第二次晋州城攻防戦に参加するなどして活躍し、文禄4年（1595年）8月に六千石加増され、播磨加古川城主（12000石）になる。
sen.e: Besides this, during the Bunroku Campaigns he was an overseer who went to Korea. In 1592 in company with Naotada SHINJO and others he issued instructions urging Korean refugees to return home. Also, in the same and subsequent (1593) year actively participated in the 2nd Jinju castle battles and in August 1595, is granted and additional 6,000 koku of land and becomes owner of Harima Kakogawa castle (12,000 koku).

sen.j: また、文禄3年（1594年）には伏見城の普請にも参加した。

sen.j: のち関ヶ原にて七本槍の中で唯一西軍に加わり、360名の兵を率いて伏見城の戦いや関ヶ原の戦い等に参加した。
sen.e: Subsequently, at Sekigahara he was the only one of the Seven lancers" to join the Western army and, participated in the Fushimi castle and Sekigahara battles etc by leading 360 troops.

sen.j: 戦後改易されるが、後に許され慶長7年（1602年）に旗本として召抱えられ、500石という小禄ながら徳川家臣となる。
sen.e: After the conflicts he suffered a change in rank but was later pardoned and in 1602 called-up as a retainer of the shogun receiving a modest 500 koku stipend as a Tokugawa vassal.

sen.j: だがその死後、糟屋家は再び断絶となった。

sen.j: また、糟屋宗孝というのは息子の名前であり、武則の死後大坂の役に豊臣方で参加し討死にしたとも言われる。
sen.e: Also, there was as son going by the name Takenori KASUYA, who after the death of Takenori (Snr.) fought on Toyotomi`s side in Osaka and is said to have died in battle.
